$HYPE @HyperliquidX #crypto

HYPE is still moving within a clear descending channel, but the structure is starting to tighten.

Price has bounced from the lower end of the channel and is now consolidating beneath mid-range resistance. This kind of compression usually precedes a larger move.

Momentum is improving. Indicators are holding higher lows while price moves sideways, showing that downside pressure is fading. Selling into this area continues to get absorbed rather than accelerated.

From a structure standpoint, holding the lower channel keeps the range-reclaim scenario intact. A push back through the middle of the range would shift the bias toward the upper end, while losing support would put the downtrend back in control.

This is a key area where patience matters. Direction should become clearer on the next expansion.

üö® Do you think my prediction about $HYPE  is going to come true or not‚ùì

The recent @aave drama is a warning to all DAOs.

Main dev and founder re-directed revenue to his own company called Aave Labs instead of AAVE token holders / DAO treasury. He did it without telling anyone.

He argues that they own the IP and website/front-end so they can do as they please there. In light of this, the AAVE governance is just smoke and mirrors. 

Plus, the founder's bio says "CEO @ Aave". Not sure how that is compatible with a DAO unless he is elected to fill such a role. @StaniKulechov any comment?

Ideally, all AAVE revenue goes to the DAO treasury and the DAO decides how it is spent. @Marczeller 

In this case, the "CEO" decided to use the brand and website he owns to redirect AAVE swap revenue to his own company without consulting the DAO.

Sounds a lot like what Uniswap did and that didn't end well. Just look at their token price. If the AAVE token wants to avoid this, they need to fix this asap. 

Otherwise, there's no point to hold AAVE tokens if the founder redirects revenue as he pleases leaving AAVE holders holding the bag. The conflict of interest is obvious. 

Worst, it seems the recent integration of Cowswap on the site came after Aave Labs was paid for it with a grant. Then they redirected user fees to themselves.

The v4 release and the Horizon market also seem to follow similar lines where more revenue goes to Aave Labs, not the DAO. Even the recent mobile app is another Aave Labs product as far as I can tell.

All of this would not matter if AAVE did not have a DAO or token. Goes to show how governance is a very difficult concept since incentives are not always aligned between stakeholders. 

I hope AAVE can find a way forward where the roles of the DAO and Aave Labs are clearly defined and not in conflict. 

Maybe they need to look at Hyperliquid where 99% of revenue goes to HYPE buy backs. The team holds and is paid in HYPE. Everyone wins. Why can't Aave Labs do the same?

The pie is big enough already or are DAOs inherently flawed?

Like, share, and follow @duonine
